text: [Music]
what we've learned in our work and what
we've also seen is that their
generational shifts and tensions and the
role of Technology - has been more
central than in say the 20th century
movements how leadership has been
experienced there in the more
contemporary movements is that they've
been the younger people are more fluid
more dynamic if you will and have a
sense of urgency that's expressed in
people have called it a leaderless
movement but we don't believe it's
leaderless its leadership that is more
fluid and accessible through media
through face-to-face interaction and
also through this very strong resistance
to old ways of knowing and being so the
challenge that we've been faced with is
how do we collaborate across generations
across identities across approaches and
discourses to bring forth something that
most of us believe in and want to
converge around but with the black lives
matter movement and me - there's
somewhat of a resistance within as it
relates to ages and as it relates to
orientations and even classes and what
you know educated formally or not and
regions of the country there are various
approaches that still face challenges to
meet to accomplish valuing black lives
valuing women's lives and bodies and
calling an end to all kinds of
ideologies that have been oppressive to
these groups one of the challenges that
we have run into in our work is the
generational dynamic around the
movements as an old person relatively
speaking there's an aspect of the sort
of discipline around issues of authority
and leadership but they did have a sort
of hegemonic hierarchical sort of flavor
to them and that really has its own
oppression within it I understand that
the contemporary movements act as if
they're leaderless but in reality there
are all kinds of Authority dynamics that
are at play and there's sometimes in my
opinion an abdication of attending to
how those influence the capacity to be
continuously effective and so as a
consequence of that we are trying to
figure out how do you grapple with the
complexity how do you have that
conversation across groups
how do you begin to really recognize
that there's a shared direction that
everyone wants to go but we haven't
figured out to even have that basic
conversation across the generations
